awd_titl_txt: Gas Phase Oxidation of Resonance-Stabilized Radicals
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division and by NSF EPSCoR, Professor Fabien Goulay from the Department of Chemistry at West Virginia University investigates combustion reaction mechanisms. The central focus is on the oxidation of large, stable free radicals which can accumulate in combustion environments.  These intermediates are known to play a major role during the formation of pollutants such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and particulate matter. Gas phase and high temperature reactions are investigated both experimentally and computationally. Experimental studies employ spectroscopic methods to characterize intermediates and their chemical behavior. This research provides critical information on reaction mechanisms that will be used to develop  more efficient combustion processes for transportation and power generation. This project also provides training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, including first generation college students and students from the Appalachian region, who have been traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. 

The project investigates the oxidation of resonance-stabilized radicals in the gas phase. These radicals can build up in appreciable concentrations and have recently been hypothesized as precursors to polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and soot. The concentration of these radicals in the gas phase is depleted mostly by oxidation reactions with very reactive species, such as the hydroxyl radical. Although theoretical studies have been performed to predict their reactivity toward the hydroxyl radicals, no experimental data are available to validate these predictions. The experimental study of radical - radical reactions is difficult because both radicals need to be formed simultaneously at sufficient concentrations. Professor Goulay and his Group produce both radicals in a flow reactor using laser photolysis, and detect their concentrations using laser spectroscopy and mass spectrometry. Theoretical calculations are used to analyze the reaction mechanisms. This work also contributes to the career development of future scientists by providing training at state-of-the-art experimental resources, including synchrotron facilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Resonance-stabilized radicals are present in gaseous carbon-rich environments (e.g. combustion and interstellar medium) where their recombination and cross- recombination reactions are proposed as a possible pathway to polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon formation. Because their oxidation by molecular oxygen is very slow, the removal of RSRs mostly occurs through radical–radical reactions with highly reactive oxygenated species. Investigating the reactivity of resonance-stabilized radicals though radical reaction can yield valuable insights into their contribution to gas-phase reaction schemes.

Our studies of gas-phase reactions over the award period have yielded significant advances in understanding the mechanisms of formation and reaction of resonance-stabilized radicals as well as their precursors. We carried out experimental and computational studies for the reactions of the free radicals with a wide range of gas phase reagents. The experiments utilized a pump-probe laser system at West Virginia University designed for measuring reaction kinetics over a wide range of experimental conditions. Product detections experiments were performed at the Advanced Light Source Synchrotron in Berkeley Ca. The experimental investigations were complemented by in-house computational studies at the M06-2X/6-311++G**//CCSD(T)/cc-pVTZ level of theory as well by RRKM-based Master Equation calculations.

The OH + propagyl reaction was investigated at the advanced light source. The reaction proceeds through the formation of a C3H3-OH adduct which can be stabilized by collision with the buffer gas. Image 1 displays the propargyl (m/z 39) and C3H3OH products (m/z 56) (left panel) and the m/z 56 photoionization upon reaction of the OH radical with propargyl. The solid lines are fit to the data using ordinary differential equations (left panel) and absolute photoionization spectra of C3H4O isomers (right panel). The branching ratios of the m/z 56 isomers are found to be temperature dependent, with acrolein becoming the dominant product at 800 K. The detected products suggest a direct addition of the OH radical onto the tail of the propargyl radical to from allenol. CO elimination is found to be the dominant channel at high temperature.

The reaction of the OH radical with cyclopentadiene was investigated both experimentally and theoretically. Image 2 displays the C5H5OH (m/z 82) and C5H6OH products (m/z 83) (left panel) and the m/z 83. The red lines are fit to double exponential functions (left panel) and the calculated photoionization spectrum of the 5-hydroxycyclopent-2-en-1-yl radical. The photoionization spectrum combined with RRKM-based Master equation calculations show that the resonance-stabilized radical is the sole addition product. Although abstraction is expected to compete with addition, especially at higher temperature, the most likely product, cyclopentadienyl, is not observed at room temperature.

The pump-probe laser technique was used to measure the reaction rate of the CH + cyclopentadiene reaction. The reaction rate coefficient is measured to be 2.70 x 10-10 cm3 s-1 at room temperature and 5.3 Torr and found to be independent of pressure with a negligible temperature dependence over the studied experimental ranges. The reaction of the methylidyne radical (CH (X2Π)) with cyclopentadiene (C5H6) was investigated in the gas phase at 4 Torr and room temperature using the kinetic machine at the ALS. The dominant product channel observed is the formation of C6H6 (m/z 78) + H. Benzene is found to be the largest contributor to the m/z 78 product channel with a relative branching ratio reported as 90 (±5)%. Several other C6H6 isomers are found to have smaller contributions, including fulvene with a branching fraction of 8%. To support the experimental branching ratios, a solution to the Master Equation is calculated on a portion of the CBS-QB3 C6H7 potential energy surface using MESMER. The computations are carried out over a range of conditions: 300-1000 K and 5-760 Torr. The resulting branching ratios support benzene as the main product. Comparison of the experimental results with the theoretical outcomes also provides valuable insights into the reaction mechanism. The formation of benzene is found to predominantly proceed via cycloaddition of the CH radical onto the unsaturated system of cyclopentadiene while fulvene is formed mainly via insertion of the radical into one of the C-H bond of cyclopentadiene.

Our research program plays on important role in the education infrastructure of West Virginia University. During the past funding period, the PI has been dedicated to the training of first-generation undergraduate and graduate college students from Appalachia. The award has been employed to support the research of students in the laboratory and travel to the ALS synchrotron. Synchrotrons are internationally renowned facilities performing some of the most advanced research. In addition, they allow young scientists to interact with high-level international researchers to promote their scientific carriers. Traveling to these facilities for WVU undergraduate and graduate students not only boots their interest in science but also expose them to state-of-the-art technologies. Image 3 shows the PI’s research group at the ALS synchrotron in November 2018. Kacee Caster and Zach Donnellan are first generation students supported by the award.


Last Modified: 11/08/2023
Modified by: Fabien Goulay
